awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Assembly and function of nectar microbial communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to study the ecology of micro-organisms (life too small to be easily seen, like yeast and bacteria) that live in the nectar of flowers. Nectar is an interesting place for such organisms to live because it doesn't last long -- most flowers last only a few days.  Yet, each flower can be home to a complex and changing "community" of yeast and bacteria; they are miniature ecosystems. Scientists will conduct experiments to explore how those micro-organisms get into nectar and whether the order in which they arrive determines the final set that end up living there.  Because each flower contains its own separate ecosystem that can be easily tweaked by scientists, this study system is a good one for understanding how ecosystems of all sizes may develop.  Such understanding is important when trying to help preserve rare species and to keep ecosystems functioning in ways that benefit both humans and wildlife.  In this project, for example, the particular set of yeast and bacteria that end up in flowers may have a large impact on what pollinators visit flowers and thus on how effectively the flowers are pollinated.  Given that a lot of what humans eat depends on pollination of crops, understanding what can lead to more effective pollination has both economic and social relevance.  High-school students will be mentored in research through a 7-week summer research internship. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will help mentor those high school students and be mentored, themselves.  Workshops on bioinformatics will be offered to train students in essential skills of data analysis.

A combination of field observations, field experiments, and laboratory experiments will be conducted on nectar microbes associated with a hummingbird-pollinated shrub in California. Data will be integrated through construction of a simulation model of plant-hummingbird-nectar microbe interactions, providing tests of community assembly theory. Researchers will integrate genetic, phylogenetic and functional dimensions of biodiversity by studying how (1) yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity are influenced by flowering phenology, (2) yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity suppress each other through antagonistic priority effects within floral nectar, (3) yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity alter hummingbirds' foraging preference by modifying nectar chemistry as a result of growth in nectar, thereby affecting functional diversity of flowers in terms of nectar chemistry, pollination success, and seed production, and (4) how functional diversity of flowers feeds back to affect yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity via altered dispersal of yeast and bacteria across flowers.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated inter-dependence of the three dimensions of biodiversity in microorganisms that inhabit floral nectar, including yeast and bacteria. The project focused on (i) genomic variation in the dominant species of nectar-inhabiting yeast (genetic diversity), (ii) species diversity of the bacteria that also colonize nectar (phylogenetic diversity), and (iii) variation in the effects of different yeast strains and bacterial species on the chemical properties of nectar and consequences for pollination and seed set (functional diversity). A combination of field observations, field experiments, and laboratory experiments were conducted on nectar microbes associated with hummingbird-pollinated monkeyflower plants in California.

In this study, we found that (1) both yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity could be influenced by flowering phenology; (2) yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity could suppress each other through antagonistic priority effects within floral nectar; (3) yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity could alter hummingbirds' foraging preference by modifying nectar chemistry as a result of growth in nectar, thereby affecting functional diversity of flowers in terms of nectar chemical composition, pollination, and seed production; and (4) functional diversity of flowers could feed back to affect yeast genetic diversity and bacterial phylogenetic diversity via altered dispersal of yeast and bacteria across flowers.

A long-standing challenge in community ecology is to predict which alternative stable state will be realized as species assemble into communities when priority effects drive community assembly. In the ecological literature on alternative stable states and priority effects, it was usually assumed that the regional species pool that supplies immigrants to local communities was static and unaffected by the dynamics of local communities. The funded research examined these commonly held but unrealistic assumptions by investigating how regional diversity of microbes was shaped by plant phenology, how local diversity within flowers was affected by dispersal from the regional species pool, and how local diversity in turn influenced regional diversity by altering hummingbird-assisted dispersal. Through this approach, findings from the research contribute to the general understanding of the role of biodiversity as both causes and consequences of alternative stable states.

Using the research, the investigators trained undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows as researchers. They also worked with local service organizations to help educate the general public about microbial ecology and their relevance to humans. In addition, this project’s focus on plant phenology made the research relevant to understanding ecological consequences of climate change. Climate-induced shifts in plant phenology are considered a major threat to conservation, but few studies have considered the potential role of nectar microbes in this context. Findings from this research on plant-pollinator-nectar microbe interactions contribute to broadening the scientific knowledge base for ecosystem management under climate change.
